details.title: Correction to "How to model reliability-growth when times of design modifications are known"

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat. & Reliability, CNR, Naples, Italy

p: Gianpaolo Pulcini received the Doctor degree (1982) in aeronautical engineering from the University of Naples, Italy.

Since 1984 he has been with the Istituto Motori of the National Research Council (CNR) of Italy where he is a Senior Researcher. His major research interests are in mechanical reliability modeling and related statistical topics.

authors.name: G. Pulcini

details.abstract: A typographical error in the log-likelihood in the paper by N. Ebrahimi (see ibid., vol.45, p.54-8, 1996) is corrected.

references.title: How to model reliability-growth when times of design modifications are known

context.text:
In the above paper [1], there is a typographical error in the log-likelihood (3)–(10), which should be
There are also several computational errors in the elements of the second-derivatives matrix \$D(\lambda_1,\,\ldots,\,\lambda_m,\,\beta)\$:

1
Equations (3)–(15b) should be

2
Equations (3)–(15c) should be

3
Equations (3)–(15e) should be

 As a consequence, the approximate 95% CI for model parameters in the numerical example of [1]are wrong, also.

the element \$d_{(m+1),\,(m+1)}\$, evaluated at \$\mathhat{\beta}\$ and \$\mathhat{\lambda}_j\$, could be written, according to [1], as
(The unrestricted MLE of the \$s\$-expected number of failures up to \$T\$, equals \$n\$.).

However, when the restricted MLE, \$\skew 3\mathhat{\mathhat{\beta}}\$ and \$\mathhat{\mathhat{\lambda}}_j\$, \$(j=1,\,\ldots,\,m)\$ are used, as in the example of [1], then
(the restricted MLE of the \$s\$-expected number of failures up to \$T\$ is not \$n\$ any more); hence
By using the \$s\$-normal approximation for the distribution of the restricted MLE, the correct lower and upper limits for the numerical example of [1] are

.
The correct approximate CI are quite larger than the wrong intervals in [1], which appear to be excessively narrow in view of the small number of failures in each stage.

links.abstract: Engineers often make changes during system development in order to correct design weaknesses. If done well this results in reliability growth as development continues. Since no reliability-growth model is adequate for all time (any growth model is valid only for some finite amount of time) it is prudent to use a different reliability model between each two design modifications. This paper assumes that the reliability growth model between each two design modifications is either a Poisson process ...

references.text: N. Ebrahimi, "How to model reliability-growth when times of design modifications are known", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 45, pp. 54-58, Mar. 1996.

nonIeee.title: Bayesian reliability assessment of repairable systems during multi-stage development programs
nonIeee.displayText: Maurizio Guida, Gianpaolo Pulcini, "Bayesian reliability assessment of repairable systems during multi-stage development programs", IIE Transactions, vol. 37, pp. 1071, 2005, ISSN 15458830.
